page.title: 04Deeside Industrial Estate
page.content: The fist part of the Industrial Estate was formed at the end of the 19th century when British Steel reclaimed marsh land which covered 980 acres.In this land many miles of roadways and also railways were laid out to enable British Steel to transport the steel they made to their customers.Later the Welsh Development Agency bought part of R.A.F.Sealand and transformed this into the part of Deeside Idustrial Estate.When the government decided to finish steel making at Shotton in 1980.British Steel provided 500 acres of land to the Welsh Development Agency to help to create more jobs for the people of Deeside and the many redundant Steel workers.Such firms as Harrison Monarch,Hyphen,Wirral Builders,Squibb Surgicare took advantage of the offer of 3 years' rent-free tenancy of small factories.
